tossups.question: A contentious instance of this feat was supposedly confirmed in 1999 when data inputted into Goosy matched predictions made by Robert Smolańczuk. A recent book by Kit Chapman notes that Al Ghiorso was this feat’s all-time champion. GSI researchers examined magnetic tape records to discover that a Bulgarian-American named Victor Ninov had lied about achieving this feat in the early 2000s. Equipment was recently upgraded to make achieving this feat easier at (*) RIKEN, which last achieved this feat in 2004 under Kōsuke Morita. A 2002 instance of this feat at Dubna honored the still-living Yuri Oganessian. Achieving this feat may become easier once an "island of stability" is reached. Claims of achieving this feat are assessed by Paul Karol’s working group at IUPAC. For 10 points, name this feat that adds a new entry to the periodic table.
tossups.answer: discovering a new element [or making a new element or synthesizing a new element or similar; or confirming the existence of a new element; accept discovering a new atom] (Kit Chapman's book is Superheavy.)

tossups.question: "Little Red" and "Little Green" are two "leaning mailboxes" in this country that commemorate a 2015 typhoon that killed 59 people. After a 2020 visit from State Department official Keith Krach, this country ended a ban on US pork imports. In June 2020, voters in a southern port city in this country approved the first-ever recall of a mayor after that politician lost a bid to become its President. Arizona will soon be the site of a new plant for a company from this country that is the world's most valuable (*) semiconductor foundry. TSMC is based in this country, where US visits prompted another country to release a video showing H-6 bombers attacking it that borrowed clips from Transformers. For 10 points, name this island country whose parliament is governed by the "Three Principles of the People" developed by Sun Yat-sen.
tossups.answer: Taiwan [or Republic of China; or ROC; or Zhōnghuá mínguó]

tossups.question: This novel's translator Anthea Bell added numerous phrases of the form "said [this book's title character]" to remind readers that it had a narrator. During a discussion in the Greenwich Observatory, the title character of this novel relates how he's never owned a clock and finds them ridiculous. The protagonist of this novel first hears of another person with his last name during a radio broadcast about the early memories of Fred Astaire and learns info about his Welsh family from his principal Penrod Smith. This novel's title character, an architectural historian, travels to (*) Prague, where he meets Vera Rysanova, who worked as a maid for his birth parents. The title character's Bloomsbury office is evoked in one of this novel's many interspersed photos. For 10 points, name this final novel by W. G. Sebald, whose title character shares his surname with a Napoleonic battle.
tossups.answer: Austerlitz

tossups.question: This artist starred opposite Mandy Patinkin in the "apocalyptic vaudeville" The Last Two People on Earth. An "all ages" play by this artist had audience members sit in a ball pit. The guilt-ridden midwife Carol appears in a scatological play by this artist whose set is littered with corpses with working penises. The designer Machine Dazzle created elaborate costumes for a performance by this ukelele player featuring Bayard Rustin's March on Washington and a musical battle between Walt Whitman and Stephen Foster. This artist uses the pronoun (*) "judy." A show by this artist stretches from 1776 to the present over 24 hours. Nathan Lane's character cleans up after a Roman bloodbath in a play by this author that riffs on Shakespeare. For 10 points, name this drag performer behind A 24-Decade History of Popular Music and Gary: A Sequel to Titus Andronicus.
tossups.answer: Taylor Mac [or Taylor Mac Bowyer]

tossups.question: After leaving one of these buildings, a man who once served as a TED ("ted") fellow ordered an Uber under the name "Oswaldo Trump." The PR agent Alejandro Cao de Benós regularly visits one of these buildings and is the official owner of all websites connected with them. A 56-year-old employee working in one of these buildings jumped out of a balcony and then crawled through a tennis court to warn local authorities about a (*) raid on one of them led by Adrian Hong. The phrase "we shall rise" was spray-painted on the wall of one of these buildings in Kuala Lumpur in 2019 in the leadup to the Hanoi summit. A raid on one of these buildings in Spain is defended by the website Freedom for Free Joseon. For 10 points, name this type of diplomatic building controlled by the government of Kim Jong-un.
tossups.answer: North Korean embassy [or embassy of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea; or embassy of the DPRK; accept synonyms for "embassy" such as high commission or permanent mission or consulate or legation for North Korea; prompt on partial answers]

tossups.question: Brian F. Allan's models of this disease's spread blame the same cause as Jim Harding's Slate article about TIMO and REIT landholdings. Porochista Khakpour's memoir Sick describes a severe form of this disease that may present with mononeuritis multiplex or third-degree heart block. An unreliable two-step test for this disease includes an EIA followed by an IgM and IgG Western blot for proteins like BmpA and (*) OspC. Bartonella, Babesia ("buh-BEE-zee-uh"), and Anaplasma often co-infect patients with this disease, whose so-called "literate" doctors break with CDC practice by offering long ceftriaxone courses for its controversial "late-stage" "post-treatment syndrome." Forest fragmentation has disrupted this disease's main reservoirs, white-footed mice and white-tailed deer. For 10 points, the spirochaete Borrelia burgdorferi causes what tick-borne disease that has expanded out of New England?
tossups.answer: Lyme disease [or Lyme borreliosis; prompt on borreliosis or Borrelia before read; accept chronic Lyme disease or CLD or late-stage Lyme disease or post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome or PTLDS; accept the "Lyme wars" or "Lyme-literate MDs"; accept Lyme encephalopathy or Lyme carditis; prompt on encephalopathy or carditis]

tossups.question: A book by this author challenges John de Graaf's Affluenza for promoting "the Over-Consumption Myth" and attacks another myth that paints failure as "immoral." George Mason professor Todd Zywicki challenged this author's focus on medical and housing costs, criticizing this author and Oren Bar-Gill for analogizing appliances like "exploding toasters" to refinancing. This author claimed that mothers served as "all-purpose safety nets" in a book arguing that "traditional" families of earlier generations had more (*) discretionary income. This author, J. L. Westbrook, and Teresa Sullivan wrote a 1989 study of credit card debt. This author of As We Forgive Our Debtors and The Two-Income Trap also wrote the 2007 paper "Unsafe at Any Rate," which effectively provided the framework for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. For 10 points, what senator had a plan to reform bankruptcy as part of her 2020 bid for president?
tossups.answer: Elizabeth Warren [or Elizabeth Ann Warren; or Elizabeth Ann Herring; or Liz Warren; accept her daughter and Two-Income Trap co-author Amelia Warren Tyagi or Amelia Louise Warren Tyagi]

tossups.question: A state-owned company in this country is still on the hook for finishing a multi-billion-dollar project in Finland called Olkiluoto ("OL-kee-lwo-toh"). After copper thieves stole wire from a lab near this country's capital in 2010, its Andra agency has spent over 10 million dollars trying to mitigate cancer risks. This country's Wattway project was too loud and too inefficient to be a practical solar-powered road. A "vacuum vessel" is a key component of a facility being built in this country as part of the multi-national (*) ITER project, which seeks to produce 500 megawatts of power via thermonuclear fusion. The EDF manages 58 nuclear reactors in this country, whose reliance on nuclear power was a big issue in a 2012 presidential campaign won by the Socialist Party. For 10 points, name this country where early radiation research was conducted at Arcueil (“ar-KUH-ee”) by the Polish scientist Marie Curie.
tossups.answer: France [or La France; or French Republic; or République française]

tossups.question: A film by this director begins at a bar with a voice-over of a phone call in which a student insists she isn't cheating on her boyfriend. In another film by this director, a man carries a bouquet of pink flowers while he gives another man a ride home on his motorcycle. A film by this man controversially ends with the protagonist closing his eyes and then switches to videotape as Louis Armstrong's "St. James Infirmary" plays and the fourth wall is broken. This man's films often use stationary cameras mounted inside (*) cars, such as in the shots that follow Akiko's taxi rides in Like Someone in Love. A film by this man recorded the trial of a cinephile who impersonated Mohsen Makhmalbaf ("MAKH-mall-boff"). In another of his films, Mr. Badii looks for someone to bury him after he commits suicide. For 10 points, name this director of Close-Up and Taste of Cherry, an Iranian.
tossups.answer: Abbas Kiarostami

tossups.question: The December 2017 suicide of ZTE engineer Ōu Jiànxīn (“oh j’yen-sheen") became a rallying cry in China against this practice, where it is legal. The Supreme Court ruled that the 11th Amendment prevented physics professor J. Daniel Kimel from suing Florida State University over this issue. A 2019 settlement over this practice granted the ACLU three years of special access to Facebook to ensure that the company's ad tools prohibited this practice, a violation of the ADEA. ProPublica found widespread evidence of this practice at a company headed by Ginni Rometty. It's unrelated to (*) race, gender, or disability, but economist David Neumark demonstrated this practice by sending out fake résumés. A lawsuit against IBM found evidence of a memo recommending this policy that mentioned "gray hairs." For 10 points, name this type of discrimination that might make certain jobs only open to Millennials.
tossups.answer: age discrimination [or ageism; prompt on discrimination; accept Age Discrimination in Employment Act]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. The day after this event, Russia's largest TV network unusually aired a historical drama based on the book Post Mortem. A much-criticized investigator of this event survived shooting himself in the head during a press conference. An ethnomusicologist was weirdly hired to propagate the "lie" about this event described in Anne Applebaum's Twilight of Democracy. Prior to this event, a politician had planned to kick off a presidential campaign at the site of a 1940 massacre. Documentarian Anita Gargas interviewed conspiracists who claimed that before this event, they saw metal (*) falling to the ground. Andrzej Błasik ("AHND-zhay BWA-sheek") told an underling to disregard the fog just prior to this event, which caused power to pass to a twin brother. Eighteen members of Parliament were killed in, for 10 points, what disaster that killed the leader of a European country's Law and Justice Party?
tossups.answer: the plane crash that killed Lech Kaczyński [or 2010 Polish plane crash; or Smolensk plane crash; or Smolensk conspiracy; or 2010 Polish Air Force Tu-154 crash; accept anything indicating that the prime minister of Poland was killed in a plane crash] (The historical drama is Andrzej Wajda’s Katyń.)

tossups.question: This "radically unhandy man" described how work "put me in a relationship to the world that often seemed abstract, glancing, secondhand" in a book about building a writer's room for himself. In his breakthrough 1991 book, he posited that man should imagine himself as a gardener. A 2016 Netflix documentary adapted a book on transformations by this author divided into chapters on Earth, Air, Fire, and Water. For a 2018 book, he used "White-Coat Shamanism" to sample mind-altering substances such as LSD. This American author of Second Nature popularized the term (*) "nutritionism," the false idea that individual compounds and ingredients are the key to good health. He ended a screed against modern agribusiness by describing his attempt to hunt and kill a wild boar. For 10 points, name this author of How to Change Your Mind and The Omnivore's Dilemma.
tossups.answer: Michael Pollan [or Michael Kevin Pollan]

tossups.question: In 2020, Dominican protesters denounced the practice of buying poor people this food in exchange for PLD votes. Belgrade Gardens used a variant of djuvec ("JOO-vetch") to create a Serbian-American variant of this food that is now a staple of Barberton, Ohio. This food's Indiana variant features extra black pepper. This food names a company whose Pakistani patrons often also purchase Zinger Burgers. It's not pizza or King Castella cakes, but the Kim family is hinted to have lost money in the boom for (*) Korean corner restaurants selling this food in the film Parasite. "Flying Lesson" by Yo La Tengo references the restaurant Prince's, which makes this food without using sauces. An extra-spicy variant of this food was popularized by Hattie B's in Nashville. This food is paired with a breakfast dish at Roscoe's. For 10 points, name this flagship product of KFC.
tossups.answer: fried chicken [prompt on partial answer; accept Southern fried chicken or hot chicken; accept pica pollo; accept chicken and waffles; prompt on chicken or chicken sandwiches or pollo]

tossups.question: One head of this organization moved to hosting the Big Bad Morning Show after being convicted of abusing his expense account. The downfall of a particularly corrupt branch of this organization is chronicled in the book I Got a Monster. An independent auditor found that this organization lied about the safeguards in its AIR program, a drone surveillance program funded by billionaire John Arnold. Wayne Jenkins led its controversial Gun Trace Task Force. Gene Ryan, the head of a union of people who work for this organization, defended a (*) "pullback" in 2015, a year in which 344 people were murdered. After a man in the custody of this organization suffered fatal injuries, protestors set a CVS on fire and the National Guard was called in by Governor Larry Hogan. For 10 points, name this law enforcement agency that faced protests following the death of Freddie Gray.
tossups.answer: Baltimore Police Department [or Baltimore PD; prompt on BPD]

tossups.question: In a play set in this country, two characters stay up all night playing a blindfolded game of Connect 4 during Harvest Day before a relative's body is found after being missing for 10 years. The narrator of a novel by an author from this country declares, "the only time you'd call the police in my area would be if you were going to shoot them" and meets the title character when she's walking and reading 19th-century novels in the park. This country is the setting of Jez Butterworth's play The Ferryman. An author from this country wrote a novel narrated by a character known only as middle sister, which features factions named "renounces" and "the opposite (*) religion." An author from this country won the 2018 Man Booker Prize for her novel Milkman. For 10 points, name this constituent country of the UK, the setting of Claran Carson's poem "Belfast Confetti."
tossups.answer: Northern Ireland [or Tuaisceart Éireann; prompt on United Kingdom or UK or Great Britain; do NOT accept or prompt on "Ireland" or "Republic of Ireland" or "England"] (Anna Burns wrote Milkman.)

tossups.question: Alfred Sitorus heads a group in this city that forms human chains to keep motorcycles from using sidewalks; poor pedestrian infrastructure made it the world's least-walked major city in 2017. During a 2013 flood in this city, a head of state was photographed paddling to his official residence, prompting this city to launch a controversial cloud seeding effort. Until an MRT opened in 2019, this city was the most populous in the world to lack an underground transport system, although it is home to a local Uber/WeChat rival called (*) Gojek ("go-jek"). Although this city is crossed by 13 rivers, constant drilling for drinking water has caused parts of it to sink 25 centimeters per year. In April 2019, planning minister Bambang Brodjonegoro ("BRO-jo-neg-GO-ro") announced that the government will be moving its administration away from this island metropolis to East Kalimantan. For 10 points, name this capital of Indonesia.
tossups.answer: Jakarta

tossups.question: This technology came in between DDT and Red Dye No. 2 on a 2010 Time Magazine list of the worst inventions of all time. One of the most popular forms this technology is made by Celemony. This technology was developed by a former Exxon engineer who used his expertise in locating drilling sites to commercialize this tech with the Antares company. The most famous version of this technology has settings like Humanize. To raise awareness of this technology, (*) Ben Gibbard wore a blue badge to a 2009 awards ceremony. Off-brand versions of this technology include an iPhone app by the artist behind "Buy U A Drank." A YouTube series originally named for this technology by the Gregory Brothers had a huge hit with "Bed Intruder Song." This technology was once known as the Cher effect because it was first prominently used in "Believe." For 10 points, name this pitch-correcting software.
tossups.answer: Autotune [accept pitch-correction or similar before the end; accept Songify the News or Auto-Tune the News; prompt on music editing technology or producing software or similar; prompt on the Cher effect]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. Brent Ohlendorf capitalized on this type of policy with the company "OK." These types of laws have been a big boon for Aardvark, which sells some products made from hemp. An editorial by Alice Wong noted that "one person's social prop is another person's conduit" and argued that these policies harmed the disabled community. A "500 million per day" stat often used to justify these policies derives from an (*) educated guess made by a 9-year-old. The impetus for many of these laws was a 2015 video posted by PhD student Christine Figgener shot near Costa Rica. The lack of good alternatives meant that one of these policies in San Francisco threatened the city's many boba tea shops. A video of an object being pulled out of the nose of a sea turtle inspired many cities to adopt, for 10 points, what type of prohibition on single-use drinking accessories?
tossups.answer: plastic straw bans [accept anything involving prohibiting the sale of single-use plastic straws; prompt on plastic bans; do not accept or prompt on "plastic bag bans"]

tossups.question: Specific term required. A 2019 polemic by Ronald Purser outlined this practice's "truthiness problem" as part of its capitalist "McDonaldization." The Freiburg inventory measures this practice, which Germer and Siegel tied to "lovingkindness and compassion" and "open monitoring." This practice was promoted in a 2012 book by Tim Ryan. Despite Ellen Langer's research on this practice's learning benefits, C. G. Brown argued that its namesake "interventions" are "reestablishing (*) religion" in public schools. Nutritionists often teach "intuitive eating" via this practice, which emphasizes non-judgment. A course from Jon Kabat-Zinn teaches stress reduction via this practice, which Andy Puddicombe monetized with the app Headspace. This practice derives from the Pali term sati. It can scan body sensations in yoga. For 10 points, what Buddhist-inspired meditation aid focuses attention on the present moment?
tossups.answer: mindfulness [accept mindfulness meditation; accept sati or smrti before read; prompt on awareness; prompt on meditation or yoga by asking "using what specific technique?"; prompt on vipassanā or insight; accept mindfulness consultation; accept mindfulness-based stress reduction or MBSR; accept mindful yoga; accept McMindfulness; accept Freiburg mindfulness inventory; accept mindfulness-based interventions; accept; Debating Yoga and Mindfulness in Public Schools: Reforming Secular Education or Reestablishing Religion?; accept mindful eating; accept A Mindful Nation]

tossups.question: Raúl Boncodin insists that a high-profile protest against this product in the Philippines in August 2013 was staged by a far-left group called the KMP. This product is backed by the organization IRRI, which is part of the CGIAR consortium. Ed Regis's 2019 book about the "imperiled birth" of this product quotes Benedikt Härlin as stating that it posed a "moral dilemma" for Greenpeace. This product, which won a Patents for Humanity award, has largely been blocked due to Principle 15 of the Cartagena Protocol, which is commonly known as the (*) precautionary principle. This product, which is partially derived from the bacterium Erwinia and daffodils, is still generally banned in the countries that could most benefit from its blindness-preventing nutrient. For 10 points, name this controversial crop genetically engineered to include beta-carotene, named for its distinctive color.
tossups.answer: golden rice [accept Golden Rice 2; prompt on genetically engineered rice or Oryza sativa; prompt on GMOs or genetically modified food; accept Golden Rice: The Imperiled Birth of a GMO Superfood.] (IRRI is the International Rice Research Institute.)

bonuses.leadin: Several writers have critiqued the dominance of MFA programs. For 10 points each:
answers: Elif Batuman
Junot Díaz
Natasha Trethewey ("TRETH-uh-way")
parts: The n+1 collection MFA vs. NYC features this author's essay "The Invisible Vocation." This author's study of Russian literature informed her books The Possessed and The Idiot.

This author responded to MFA vs. NYC by critiquing white-dominated programs in his essay "MFA vs. POC." In 2018, Zinzi Clemmons claimed that she had been sexually harassed by this author of The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao.

Toi Derricotte co-founded the Cave Canem ("KAH-vay KAH-nem") Foundation to counteract the underrepresentation of African-American poets in MFA programs. The organization's first prize went to this poet of Native Guard and Bellocq's Ophelia who was appointed US Poet Laureate in 2012.

bonuses.leadin: Harada, Li, and Kamachi formed a "molecular necklace" from one of these structures by threading cyclodextrins on a PEG chain. For 10 points each:
answers: rotaxanes
nanoscale [or nanoscopic scale; or nanometer scale; accept nanomachines or nanites; accept nanotechnology or nanoscience or nanorobotics or nanosystems]
dip-pen nanolithography [or DPN; prompt on nib pen or pen nib or quill pen]
parts: Name these dumbbell-shaped mechanically interlocked molecular architectures that, along with catenanes and knots, are promising switches for molecular electronics.

Rotaxanes are building blocks of molecular machines at this scale, like the assemblers promoted by K. Eric Drexler. Richard Smalley developed material "technology" at this scale, which is on the order of 10 to the negative ninth meters.
Nanostructures can be fabricated using this form of nanolithography, which delivers molecular "inks" like alkanethiols ("alkane-thiols") to a substrate like gold using an atomic force microscope tip.

bonuses.leadin: This city's International Jazz Festival bills itself as "Africa's largest gathering," as it is the largest music event on the continent. For 10 points each:
answers: Cape Town [or Kaapstad; or iKapa; prompt on Cape Jazz]
Abdullah Ibrahim [or Dollar Brand; prompt on Dollar]
Duke Ellington [or Duke Ellington; or Edward Kennedy Ellington]
parts: Name this city whose International Jazz Festival honored Hugh Masekela in 2018. Musicians here often play in its historic Greenmarket Square.

Cape Town's native jazz stars include this pianist who wrote the anti-apartheid song "Mannenberg." This father of New York rapper Jean Grae reunited with Masekela, his old Jazz Epistles bandmate, for a final Cape Town show in 2018.
Ibrahim credits this pianist, who highlighted Ibrahim's "Dollar Band Trio" in the 1960s, as a major influence. His orchestra popularized such standards as "Take the 'A' Train."

bonuses.leadin: Alla Lileeva and Daniel Trefler found that tariff cuts increased this measure at the "plant level" for some Canadian plants. For 10 points each:
answers: labor productivity [accept being productive, but prompt on production; accept output per worker; prompt on output or efficiency; accept productivity growth; accept the productivity-wage gap or productivity-pay gap or productivity-compensation gap or similar; accept plant-level productivity]
technologies [or technological progress or word forms; accept IT or information technology; accept computerization; anti-prompt on other specific technologies; prompt on inventions or similar]

job skills [prompt on tasks by asking "allocating what to tasks?"; do not accept or prompt on "jobs"; accept "The Skill Content of Recent Technological Change"; accept "Skills, Tasks and Technologies: Implications for Employment and Earnings"]
parts: Name this measure that has diverged from wages since the 1970s, forming a "gap." Hall and Jones associated this measure with latitude, speaking an "international language," and disfavoring diversion in an analysis across 127 countries.

Authors like Erik Brynjolfsson have discussed a "paradox" of falling productivity despite these advances, which are measured with total factor productivity. These innovations might be opposed by anarcho-primitivists or neo-Luddites.

David Autor analyzed how technological change has altered demand for these intangible things. With Daron Acemoğlu ("DAH-roan ah-jay-MOH-loo"), Autor challenged the "canonical model" with a continuum for allocating these things.

bonuses.leadin: On an episode of the show spun off from this comic, Werner Herzog films a documentary about the 2008 presidential election. For 10 points each:
answers: The Boondocks (Huey Newton wrote Revolutionary Suicide.)
Martin Luther King, Jr. [or MLK]
The Source
parts: Name this comic strip collected in A Right to be Hostile, which was often moved to newspaper editorial pages for its political content. Its protagonist was named for the author of Revolutionary Suicide.

In a controversial Boondocks episode, this man survives his assassination and wakes up from a coma shortly before 9/11. In 2017, Arkansas finally stopped recognizing Robert E. Lee Day on the same day as this man's federal holiday.
Early versions of the Boondocks strip appeared in this long-running magazine, whose "Unsigned Hype" column helped rappers like The Notorious B.I.G. hit it big.

bonuses.leadin: This phase can create a segmented flow regime as an alternative to continuous-flow in chemical reactors. For 10 points each:
answers: droplet-based microfluidics [accept digital microfluidics or DMF; prompt on emulsions; prompt on anything on-a-chip]
electrowetting [accept types like optoelectrowetting or photoelectrowetting; accept EWOD or electrowetting on dielectric; accept word forms; prompt on wetting]
liquid lenses [accept objective lenses]
parts: Identify this dispersed phase formed in a discrete, well-controlled manner by a specific type of microfluidic device that can run combinatorial reactions in parallel. T-junctions can generate this phase with high monodispersity.

This technique can manipulate droplets on tiny chips by altering their interfacial tension. The Young–Lippmann equation describes the contact angle in this technique that is often applied "on dielectric."

Electrowetting can create these devices from two immiscible liquids and alter their shape to make them converging, flat, or diverging. 4Pi confocal microscopy uses two "objective" optical devices of this kind.

bonuses.leadin: Reviews of this director's 2020 film Matthias & Maxime often opined that its less frenetic style played poorly. For 10 points each:
answers: Xavier Dolan ("gzahv-YAY doh-LAWN") [or Xavier Dolan-Tadros]
Cannes Film Festival [or Festival de Cannes; prompt on International Film Festival]
Lady Bird
parts: Name this youthful director from Montreal, who both starred in and directed his 2009 debut I Killed My Mother. His other films about mother–son relationships include The Death & Life of John F. Donovan and Mommy.
Xavier Dolan's Laurence Anyways competed in the Un Certain Regard section of this film festival and thus was not eligible for its Palme d'Or.

Dolan was hired to interview Timothée Chalamet by VMAN magazine. Chalamet played the insufferable Kyle Scheible in this film, whose title character seeks to leave Sacramento for "where the culture is" on the East Coast.

bonuses.leadin: An article in GQ described a search for a "billion-dollar" example of these facilities simply known as "The Machine." For 10 points each:
answers: meth labs [or methamphetamine laboratories; prompt on labs or laboratories or drug dens or drug labs]
Myanmar [or Burma; or Republic of the Union of Myanmar; or Pyidaunzu Thanmăda Myăma Nainngandaw]
Shan State
parts: Name these facilities that are the major source of income for the National Liberation Army of Arakan, which uses them to make products such as yaba.
Proceeds from meth sales finance many of this country's rebel groups, which often employ refugees from its Rohingya ("ro-HIN-juh") conflict to do the trafficking.

In May 2020, Myanmar's army seized 100 million dollars of meth in this state. This state's lawless north was the longtime base of "Opium King" Khun Sa, who surrendered with his 20,000 soldiers in 1996 and was allowed to live out his last years in luxury.

bonuses.leadin: In one novel by this author listed on the New Yorker's "20 Writers for the 21st Century," Larry hires a stranger on the internet to say the title prayer for his dead father. For 10 points each:
answers: Nathan Englander
Philip Roth [or Philip Milton Roth]
Z [accept The Lost City of Z]
parts: Identify this author of kaddish.com and What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank.

What We Talk About When We Talk About Anne Frank was partially inspired by this author's The Ghost Writer. His flourishing later career included Zuckerman novels like The Human Stain and American Pastoral.

The protagonist of Englander's 2017 novel Dinner at the Center of the Earth is a onetime Israeli operative known only by this short name. This is also the last word in the title of a David Grann book about British explorer Percy Fawcett.

bonuses.leadin: Counties that house these institutions tend to artificially benefit from the census, which counts people as residing in these places rather than their hometowns. For 10 points each:
answers: prisons [or jails; or equivalents]
Philadelphia [or nicknames like Philly]
Al Capone [or Alphonse Gabriel Capone; prompt on Scarface]
parts: Identify these institutions. Many Floridians who had spent time in these institutions were granted the right to vote in a 2018 referendum.

A 2018 study by sociologists Remster and Kramer found that abolishing prison-based gerrymandering would gain this city at least one additional seat in the state legislature. Alice Goffman's On the Run: Fugitive Life in an American City is set in this city.

Philly’s shuttered Eastern State Penitentiary now operates as a museum where you can visit a well-furnished cell once occupied by this man. This man’s decline and early death in Miami Beach is depicted in a 2020 biopic ("bio-pick") starring Tom Hardy.

bonuses.leadin: Jerome Karabel's "hidden history" The Chosen explores exclusionary policies at three of these universities. For 10 points each:
answers: The Ivy League [or the Ivies; accept the Ancient Eight; accept "Don't Send Your Kid to the Ivy League"; anti-prompt on HYP or Harvard or Yale or Princeton or other specific Ivy League schools]

leadership [or ability to lead or being a leader; or word forms; accept Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead; accept leadership ambition gap; accept Full Range Leadership Model or transformational leadership or laissez-faire leadership or transactional leadership or leadership styles]
Daniel Goleman
parts: Name this elite group of universities that William Deresewicz ("duh-REZ-uh-wits") criticized in Excellent Sheep and dismissed as "overrated" in a 2014 New Republic cover article.

Deresewicz argued that the Ivy League overemphasizes this quality, which the Full Range Model divides into transactional, laissez-faire, and transformational styles. Women face an "ambition gap" for attaining this quality according to Sheryl Sandberg's book Lean In.
This former Yale Child Studies Center researcher identified six leadership styles and argued that "What Makes a Leader" is emotional intelligence, a concept he popularized in a 1995 book.

bonuses.leadin: A section of this country's penal code lends its name to people who commit 419 scams. For 10 points each:
answers: Nigeria [or Federal Republic of Nigeria; or Orílẹ̀-èdè Olómìniira Àpapọ̀ Nàìjíríà; or Jamhuriyar Taraiyar Najeriya; or Ọ̀hàńjíkọ̀ Ọ̀hànézè Naìjíríyà; accept Nigerian prince scam]
fraternities [or confraternities; or frats; or fraternal organization; prompt on social clubs or men's clubs]
Yahoo! [prompt on Verizon Communications Inc.]
parts: Identify this African country whose "area boys" extort money from pedestrians, among other scams. 419 scams are sometimes known as this country's namesake prince scam.

In Nigeria, these organizations often double as organized crime syndicates. In the 1950s, Wole Soyinka co-founded one of these organizations called the National Association of Seadogs, and other notorious ones include Black Axe.
College students who pay the bills with email scams are commonly called this company's "boys" by their fellow Nigerians. Marissa Mayer was CEO of this company from 2012 to 2017.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about British art heists, for 10 points each.
answers: a golden toilet
Annibale Carracci ("ahn-NEE-bah-lay ka-RACH-chee") (The painting is The Butcher's Shop.)
Barbara Hepworth [or Dame Jocelyn Barbara Hepworth] (Maclean’s book is Circles and Squares: The Lives and Art of the Hampstead Modernists.)
parts: In 2019, thieves stole a golden object of this type from Blenheim Palace by Maurizio Cattelan. Cattelan designed his work to look like a real Kohler example of these objects, complete with functional plumbing.

A year later, thieves stole this artist's 1580 painting A Boy Drinking from the Christ Church Picture Gallery. C. D. Dickerson's book Raw Painting examined this artist's painting of two men posed in front of slabs of meat.

Bronze thieves likely stole this artist's Two Forms (Divided Circle) from London's Dulwich Park in 2011. Caroline Maclean traced modern British art to this member of Unit One piercing a hole in pink alabaster in 1932.

bonuses.leadin: The Hoover Institution's Larry Diamond criticized this concept as the basis for "Globalization 2.0" in Ill Winds. For 10 points each:
answers: China Model [or Běijīng Consensus; accept Zhōngguó móshì; although it is not a two-word phrase, accept Chinese Economic Model]
10 [accept Ten Points or Ten Principles of Economics]
tax system [or federal income tax system; accept tax reform]
parts: Give this two-word phrase outlined in a 2015 Daniel A. Bell book on Political Meritocracy and the Limits of Democracy. Joshua Cooper Ramo coined a version of this phrase, which Bell explicated as "a combination of economic freedom and political oppression."

The China Model is often contrasted with John Williamson's "Washington Consensus," a list of this many policy recommendations. Gregory Mankiw ("MAN-kyoo") outlined this many basic principles of economics.
The Washington Consensus calls for reforming these systems. Grover Norquist has convinced many Republicans to sign a pledge not to increase rates in the US's system of this type.

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, an Israeli delegation to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species proposed giving this long-extinct animal a new Appendix II classification. For 10 points each:
answers: woolly mammoths [or Mammuthus primigenius; accept more specific mammoths like Columbian mammoth or South African mammoth]
Lena River [or Eljune]
Long Now Foundation [accept Clock of the Long Now]
parts: Identify these extinct large mammals that some groups want to label "endangered" to crack down on elephant ivory poachers who fraudulently claim that the ivory came from these species.
Mammoth ivory is so lucrative that people have taken to blasting water cannons into the permafrost in this Siberian river’s delta. This river is to the east of the Yenisey and Ob Rivers.
This non-profit has funded George M. Church's attempts to clone a mammoth–elephant hybrid. This group's namesake clock plans to run for at least 10,000 years.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about recent books by people who grew up in sheltered communities, for 10 points each.
answers: Jehovah's Witnesses [or JW; prompt on Christianity]
Educated
Westboro Baptist Church [or WBC; prompt on Westboro Church]
parts: Amber Scorah's memoir about "Leaving" this sect records how she was banned from attending her father's funeral for having premarital sex. Clara Bowden's mother is a devout member of this sect in Zadie Smith’s White Teeth, but Clara realizes that two million of them won't make it into heaven.

This 2018 Tara Westover memoir details her father's disappointment with the world not ending on Y2K. Later in this book, Westover self-studies for the ACT and faces culture shock at Brigham Young University.
Megan Phelps-Roper's memoir Unfollow describes how she held anti-gay signs at military funerals as part of this fringe church once headed by Fred Phelps.

bonuses.leadin: In the Gundy case, the Supreme Court came close to limiting Congress's delegation power. For 10 points each:
answers: sex offenders [or sex abuser; or sexual offender; or sexual predators; accept answers like people convicted of a sex crime or rapists; prompt on partial answer]
Brett Kavanaugh [or Brett Michael Kavanaugh]
snowmobiles [or motor sled; or skimobile; or snow scooter; or Ski-doo; prompt on vehicles]
parts: The Gundy case centered on SORNA, a 2006 act honoring Adam Walsh that severely restricted the freedom of these people. The 2003 case of Smith v. Doe upheld a series of laws making life worse for these people.
Had this Supreme Court justice been confirmed a few days earlier, the Gundy decision likely would have gone the other way. Christine Blasey Ford testified at his controversial confirmation hearing.

Without delegation power, the Department of the Interior would no longer be able to set rules about these things. In 2013, new rules limited the use of these noisy things to no more than 50 groups per day in Yellowstone.

bonuses.leadin: A "biography" of this disease begins with a hieroglyph ascribed to Imhotep, which was deciphered by Edwin Smith in 1862. For 10 points each:
answers: cancer [accept specific cancers; prompt on tumors or neoplasms]
surgical checklists [accept The Checklist Manifesto]
ASA physician status classification system [or ASA grade; or American Society of Anesthesiologists grade]
parts: Identify this class of diseases that appears in the subtitle of Siddhartha Mukherjee's book The Emperor of All Maladies.

Another physician-turned-essayist, Atul Gawande ("guh-WAHN-day"), published a 2009 study showing that these things reduced complications following non-cardiac surgery. Gawande argued that a study which concluded that these things didn't work in Ontario was plagued by poor methodology.

One step on the WHO's surgical checklist is to assess the patient's grade on a system named for this medical specialist organization, which ranges from 1 for a healthy person to 6 for a brain-dead patient about to have their organs removed.

bonuses.leadin: Mysterious America author Loren Coleman delineated these beings into "phantoms" and "stalkers." For 10 points each:
answers: phantom clowns [accept rough equivalents like harlequins or jesters; accept Bad Clowns]
It
St. Louis [or STL]
parts: Identify these beings, whose sightings in places like Greenville inspired a mass social panic in 2016. Benjamin Radford wrote a guide to "bad" versions of these beings.

Some people thought the "great clown panic of 2016" was a guerrilla marketing campaign for the 2017 movie adaptation of this Stephen King novel, in which a demonic monster terrorizes children as Pennywise the Dancing Clown.

Rajiv Joseph wrote the libretto for an opera based on Salman Rushdie's novel Shalimar the Clown, which premiered at this city's opera theatre. During the '90s, many Bosnians settled in this city, where the Citygarden sculpture park opened in 2009.

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, the government of Binyamin Netanyahu put up a sign honoring this man in Brukhim ("broo-KHEEM"), at a planned Golan Heights settlement now named for him. For 10 points each:
answers: Donald Trump [accept Trump Heights or Trump Tower]
Poland [or Republic of Poland; or Rzeczpospolita Polska]
Baku, Azerbaijan [or Bakı]
parts: Identify this politician whose namesake Organization is based in a Tower also named for him on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

This country has long desired a US military base, with some politicians offering to name it Fort Trump to sweeten the deal. The Obama administration cancelled the EIS missile defense base in this country.

Trump's name also appears on a tower in this city built by the Mammadov family, who are closely linked to Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps. Adam Davidson noted that the next-most-fancy hotel in this city, AYF Palace, sells rooms for only 40 dollars a night.
